div.p: SHAFT of a Column, in building, is the body thereof between the baſe and capital ; ſo called from its straightneſs, See Architecture.
Shaft, in mining, is the pit or hollow entrance into the mine. In the tin-mines, after this is ſunk about a fathom, they leave a little, long, ſquare place, which is called a shamble.

Shafts are ſunk ſome ten, ſome twenty fathoms deep into the earth, more or leſs. Of theſe ſhafts, there is the landing or working ſhaft, where they bring up the work or ore to the ſurface ; but if it be worked by a horſe engine or whim, it is called a whim-shaft ; and where the water is drawn out of the mine, it is indifferently named an eng ine-shaft, or the rod-shaft. See Mine.
